titleStmt.title: The royal chronicle: wherein is contained, an historical narration of His Majesties Royal progress; the princely cabinet laid open, with an embleme to Great Brittain; the peoples diadem, proceeding from the ornament and crown of their gracious Lord and soveraign; the incomparable studies of His Majesty in the government of Kings, to the admiration of all forreign princes; and His Majesties leige people within these His realms and dominions; His great endowments aud [sic] experience, in religion, law, and governments; His mercy rejoycing over justice, and his justice cutting out work for his mercy; His gracious pardon to offenders, and His Christian speech to the London ministers.

titleStmt.title: The royal chronicle: wherein is contained, an historical narration of His Majesties Royal progress; the princely cabinet laid open, with an embleme to Great Brittain; the peoples diadem, proceeding from the ornament and crown of their gracious Lord and soveraign; the incomparable studies of His Majesty in the government of Kings, to the admiration of all forreign princes; and His Majesties leige people within these His realms and dominions; His great endowments aud [sic] experience, in religion, law, and governments; His mercy rejoycing over justice, and his justice cutting out work for his mercy; His gracious pardon to offenders, and His Christian speech to the London ministers.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Royal Chronicle: Wherein is contained, An Hi≈øtorical Narration of His Maje≈øties Royal Progre≈øs; The Princely Cabinet laid open, with an Embleme to Great Brittain; The Peoples Diadem, proceeding from the Ornament and Crown of their gracious Lord and Soveraign; The incomparable Studies of His Maje≈øty in the Government of Kings, to the admiration of all forreign Princes; and His Maje≈øties Liege People within the≈øe His Realms and Dominions; His great Endowments and Experience, in Religion, Law, and Governments; His Mercy rejoycing over Ju≈øtice, and his Ju≈øtice cutting out work for his Mercy; His gracious Pardon to Offenders, and His Chri≈øtian Speech to the London Mini≈øters.

figure.figDesc: blazon or coat of arms of the British royal family
figure.p: HONI SOIT QVI MAY Y PENSE

div.p: LONDON, Printed for G. Horton, living near the three Crowns in Barbican. 1660.

div.head: THE Royal Chronicle:
div.p:
IF Violence and Time had con≈øpired to wear out all the Memorials of former Ages, give me leave to pre≈øent you with a brief (but plea≈øant) Chronicle to all Po≈øterity, of his Royal Maie≈øties Birth, Education, and Progre≈øs; And ≈øhould modern worth be blotted out of all Records, a re≈øtored Charles ≈øufficeth, in whom the forlorn Vertue of our wor≈øt of Times took ≈øanctuary: 'Tis his Soveraign Graces, that delights the Soules of his loyal Subjects: And we need not wonder, that Nature was 5 years meditating on the great piece that was to re≈øult from ≈øuch a Royal Conflux, both of Father and Mother; in who≈øe Bed all the Royal Families of Europe met: in his Father there was by his great Grandmother the wife of James the Fourth Britti≈øh Maie≈øty; by his Grandfather he ≈øhared of the Saxon Royalty, by his Mother of the Dani≈øh, by his Father of the Norman, by his Si≈øter he was allied to the Elector Palatine; as he was related to Denmark, ≈øo he was to Sweden and Po ‚Ä¢ and, and to mo≈øt of the German or Italian Princes; in our Soveraigns Mother there lodgeth all that's Soveraign in the Bourbons of France, the Au≈øtrians of Spain, the Medices of Fl ‚Ä¢ rence, (≈øo true is it that God made all Nations of one blood.) It was after five years mutual enjoyment of each other Charles the fir≈øt King of England, &c. and Mary Daughter to a great
and Si≈øter to a ju≈øt King of France received this Son, the ≈øacred pledge to them of Heavens, and each others Love. For He was born the 29 Day of May, 1630. St. Augu≈øtines birth-day, where we may hope this Nur≈øing Father of our Church will with his ≈øword which He bears not in vain, prove as great a Defender of the faith once delivered to the Saints, as the other Holy Father did with his pen, and we made as happy in this Crown and Scepter, as the Antient Church was in that Miter and Cro≈øier. May never knew a more hopeful Flower then this that happily ≈øprung up from the Ro≈øes of York and Lanca≈øter joyned to the Lillies of France; a flower to who≈øe compo≈øure it ≈øeems Nature ≈øummoned its divided glories, as Zouxis did his ≈øeveral Beauties to make up one Venus; well this May was then thought mo≈øt happy until now, we have lived to ≈øee another May, as much more happy, as it is to be brought to a Kingdom then to be brought to the world, to be received as a Prince into the di≈øcreet embraces of Nations, then as a Child into the fond Embraces of a Nur≈øe; to be crowned then to be cradled: Great was the remark of this Royal Infant through each tender Line, relating to ≈øo worthy a Prince, as is fit to be con≈øecrated to Solemnities worthy a Chronicle. The Heavens ≈øeemed to congratulate his royal birth, a Star appearing at mid-day over St. James, di≈øplaying its mode≈øt beams in ≈øpight of Sun-≈øhine in the middle of the Air, (an embleme of his future glory,) Thus did the Heavens expre≈øs them≈øelves in miracles and wonders; and it is our duty to admire them, as the works of the Lord, and therefore wonderful in our eyes: Yet the great Selden attempted to interpret that Star thus:
When to Pauls Cro≈øs the greatful King drew near?
A ≈øhining Star did in the Heavens appear,
Thou that con≈øult'≈øt with Divine My≈øteries,
Tell me what this bright Comet ≈øignifies?
Now is there born a valiant Prince it'h We≈øt,
That ≈øhall eclip≈øe the Kingdoms of the Ea≈øt.

The King our Soveraigns Father being ≈øen≈øible that Children to any man e≈øpecially to a Prince are an inheritance from the Lord, went ≈øolemnly to St. Pauls, (once a Cathedral, ≈øince a ≈øtable; once a Church to entertain Chri≈øt in, ≈øince a Manger for Rebels to revel in) and there acknowledged with the Emperour Antoninus in St. Pauls phra≈øe, that by God, and through God, and therefore to Him, and the glory of his prai≈øe are all things.

This Bud of Maje≈øty was committed to the care of the honourable Counte≈øs of Dor≈øet, to be by her tender hands, and softer care cheri≈øhed to grow up a Soveraign, where He ≈øucked graces in with milk, and vertues as early as nouri≈øhment; as appears by the mo≈øt incomparable gifts and graces wherewith God hath bin plea≈øed to endow his Maje≈øty. To pa≈øs by his outward Man, comelier, and with Saul higher then all the people, ≈øo that there is none like him among all the people; ≈øo exactly formed, that with Ab≈øalon from the Crown of his head to the ≈øoul of his foot the mo≈øt curious eye could not di≈øcern an error or a ≈øpot; the plea≈øing ≈øeverity and ≈øoft rigorou≈øne≈øs of that face which is both Maje≈øtick and beautiful, ≈øolemn and comely; though of late he is grown leaner with cares and age; the dark and night complexion of his face, and the twin-≈øtars of his quick and ≈øharp eyes ≈øparkling in that night; He is mo≈øt beautiful when he ≈øpeaks, his black ≈øhining Locks naturally curled into great Rings hath hitherto been his Ornament and Crown; his motions ea≈øie and graceful, and plainly Maje≈øtick! &c. I ≈øay to pa≈øs by the≈øe lower worths of neat ≈øhaped du≈øt and well framed earth, come we to his Mind which is indeed him≈øelf; which you may gue≈øs noble by that body wherein it dwels, ≈øuch Cabinets were made onely for the mo≈øt precious Jewel: the plea≈øing parts and motions of that body are emblems of his mind; beauty, comeline≈øs, proportion, &c. the gro≈øs Ornaments of the body, are ≈øo many refined vertues in his ≈øoul: 1. His va≈øt Under≈øtanding, as ≈øpreading, and as wide as the things to be under≈øtood; three Nations put limits to his power, its the world onely that confines his thoughts. His Maje≈øty under≈øtands Spani≈øh and Italian, writes French correctly; the French, Italian, Spaniards, (like tho≈øe Parthians, Medes, and Elamites in the Acts) are amazed to hear Him, replying to each of them in their own Tongue wherein they were born. In the≈øe ≈øeveral Languages he peru≈øeth ≈øuch parts of knowledge as may compleat a Soveraign: Logick ≈øeems to be his Nature as well as Rea≈øon, He cannot ≈øpeak incon≈øequently. He hath read divers of the choice≈øt pieces of policy, & gathered the ≈øcattered wi≈ødom and rea≈øon that run through Politicians writings and actions in his own brea≈øt, and there dige≈øted them into axiomes of an entire and well framed policy; to policy He hath added ancient and modern Hi≈øtory; whereupon he ≈øeeth tho≈øe things performed, that He ≈øaw in policy contri ‚Ä¢ ed. When we have admired the gracious contents of any of His Maje≈øties Writings, we cannot but admire al≈øo his excellent Rhetorick.

1. His Maje≈øty being naturally aver≈øe from that lawle≈øs power he ≈øaw exerci≈øed in the Countryes where he ≈øojourned; and re≈øolved to Govern by Laws; he proceeds to ≈øtudy the Law of Nations, and that of his own Countrey too; wherein his Father ≈øo excelled, that few Gentlemen in England came near him; his skil in Geography, what with his ≈øtudy, what with his Travels is admirable: Indeed the u≈øeful parts of the Mathematicks, the Globe, Fortification, &c. take him up very much, in Navigation, what by his own Genius, what by conver≈øe with Marinners, and his own Ob≈øervations in the Downes, and el≈øewhere, he is ≈øo good a Proficient, that expert Seamen have admired him, and dare promi≈øe that his skil that way will be no ≈ømall advantage to the Nation, who≈øe Intere≈øt lyes in forraign Voyages and Trades; But Divinity is his Mi≈øtre≈øs, with who≈øe whole≈øome principles he hath well ≈øtocked the great ≈øpirit of his mind, upon which his Soul may re≈øt; he ≈øearches that word of God which is able to make a man wi≈øe to ≈øalvation, and perfect to every good work, in a word, he hath all the advantages of knowledge. 1 A cleer apprehen≈øion to receive a right and di≈øtinct notion of the things repre≈øented to him. 2 Solidity of Judgement to weigh the particulars he apprehends. 3. Fidelity of Retention; for as Nature hath given to the bodies of men for the furtherance of Corporal ≈øtrength, a Retentive power to cla≈øp and hold fa≈øt that which pre≈øerveth it, until a thorough concoction be wrought, ≈øo he hath a Retentive faculty of Memory given to Rea≈øon as a means to con≈øolidate and inrich it.

2. His great wi≈ødome, as of an Angel of God, as large a heart to know good and evil, as great education, the difference of Nation and Factions he had to deal with, his Enemies oppo≈øition, his Friends treachery, his per≈øonal conver≈øe with men of all ≈øorts, the variety of his experience from the di≈øtinct knowledge of the Natures of the People of ≈øeveral Countreys of their chief Mini≈øters of State Eccle≈øia≈øtick and Civil, and all this as a noble Pen ob≈øerves in adver≈øity, which opens the under≈øtanding, and confirms the judgement, could make; he with his Grand-father of France carrieth a Councel with him upon one Hor≈øe.

3. But this wi≈ødome were dangerous, were it not accompanied with ju≈øtice, his wi≈ødom is not a crafty or ≈øordid ≈øubtilty, nor devili≈øh policie; but pure, good, and ju≈øt Judgement: He hath a Ju≈øtice that becomes the Throne, a con≈øtant will to give every
Man his due, as he hath well or ill de≈øerved: A per≈øon of Honour who hath ≈øpent 18 years in his Maje≈øties Court and ≈øervice, doth upon di≈øtinct knowledge let the World know he can as confidently believe that his Maje≈øty is ju≈øt as that he is a Man; he ob≈øerves a Ju≈øtice in his word, and in his action, the one is an Oracle, and the other Law.

4. But he hath a mercy that rejoyceth over his Ju≈øtice, a mercy calculated for our time and Nation, wherein Subjects were never ≈øo obnoxious to Ju≈øtice, nor a Prince ≈øo enclined to mercy; a People was hardly ever ≈øo guilty as we, and hardly a Prince ever ≈øo gratious as him≈øelf, we are not more ready to offend then he to pardon; with what tender Maje≈øty doth he pa≈øs by the guilty pro≈øtrate? his Ju≈øtice doth but cut out work for his Mercy! what ≈øtubborn Offenders that brings upon their knees, this ≈øtoops to bring them up again; they that fall by his ≈øeverity, ri≈øe up again by his favour; he is more compa≈ø≈øionate to Men then they are to them≈øelves: It is but the lea≈øt part of his mercy that he can be merciful to others while they are mo≈øt cruel to him, he is exerci≈øing the highe≈øt charity towards them, while they are exerci≈øing the greate≈øt injuries towards him; this Nature taught him, then God, and afterwards his Father, in that incomparable advice to him.

5. A general goodne≈øs, (whereof that mercy is but a branch) familiar conver≈øe, ea≈øine≈øs of acce≈øs, a readine≈øs to communicate him≈øelf, his fair carriage towards all, how unwilling he is to force men to do him right, how (when he who fears not to do others ju≈øtice) afraid is he to do it to him≈øelf? I know not whether he be more good then great, more Charlebone then Charlemaine; I am ≈øure his virtues are e≈øteemed by him more then his Kingdome, and he doth not exerci≈øe the≈øe vertues (as malice, as Hell once ≈øugge≈øted) that he might di≈ø≈øemble him≈øelf to his ju≈øt Right; but he would obtain his Right that he might be the more able to exerci≈øe his vertues; his Right will therefore plea≈øe him, becau≈øe then he is able to forgive them that did him wrong.

6. His magnanimity, fortitude, and courage; he is as magnanimous in ≈øuffering wrong, as he is valiant in attempting to recover his Right; his Innocence being guilty of nothing, is afraid of nothing, the Righteous is as bold as a Lyon, fearing no Enemy, becau≈øe he hath ju≈øtly provoked none; his Religion is not the lea≈øt
≈øupport of his valour; He with David encourageth Gari≈øons, and wraps up him≈øelf in his God, where Rea≈øon leaves doubting, their Faith begins in hope even again≈øt hope. In a word, God hath indued His Maje≈øty with tho≈øe incomparable Graces that are ≈øeldome poured forth any where below the Throne; for what≈øoever things are true, ju≈øt, pure, and lovely, they are in Him; This is the Per≈øon whom God and all Men think worthy of a Kingdom, but tho≈øe over whom He is a King; (meaning the Phanatique) the≈øe are the Vertues in who≈øe enjoyment other Nations hug them≈øelves: The≈øe are the Princely Rayes that ≈øhine with Maje≈øtick Lu≈øtre in mo≈øt parts of Europe: And this is the great and Chri≈øtian Conqueror, who attributes not any thing to Him≈øelf, but with Holy King David, giveth the glory of all to the King of Kings, ≈øaying, I wil not tru≈øt in my Bow, neither ≈øhall my Sword ≈øave me: But thou ha≈øt ≈øaved us from our enemies, and ha≈øt put them to ≈øhame that hated us; Or, as His Maje≈øty graciou≈øly expre≈ø≈øed Him≈øelf in His ≈øhort Speech to the Mini≈øters, in his pa≈ø≈øage through the City:
The deliverance which God hath wrought for me, I own as the work of his own right hand, beyond humane contrivance, and de≈øire that all the glory of them may be a≈øcribed to Him.
